Dietzia cinnamea is chemoheterotrophic, meaning it requires organic compounds as a source of carbon and energy for growth. It is capable of oxidizing a variety of carbohydrates, including glucose, fructose, and sucrose. The optimum growth temperature for this species is around 30-37°C.

Phylogenetically, Dietzia cinnamea is closely related to other members of the genus Dietzia, which are known to inhabit diverse environmental niches, including soil, water, and even clinical samples. The genus Dietzia belongs to the phylum Actinobacteria, which is a group of gram-positive bacteria known for their ability to produce a wide range of secondary metabolites.

The potential ecological roles and applications of Dietzia cinnamea are still under investigation, but its isolation from soil samples suggests that it may play a role in nutrient cycling or other soil-based processes.
